children.subject:
Thanks for your response, I will keep all this in mind and do some research on which groups I would be interested in asking. Its always good to hear that my improvement will hopefully pay off. 

I guess I just have 2 more questions:

- What does RL stand for? I feel like it either stands for Robotics Learning, or Reinforcement Learning, but I couldnt tell with a quick google search

- If I wanted to pursue a PhD in the future (especially for something like robotics), would I be able to get started by doing some sort of masters, or doing what you said in 1) to get working in some sort of lab to publish papers?

1) Find PhD students that are involved in research that you find interesting and want to be a part of and reach out to them. Usually cold emailing professor isn't super productive but certain research groups (primarily the RL people) are fine with this.

2) Depends on the field, some look down on industry experience, some are neutral, and some encourage. If your gap is only 1-2 years between undergrad and grad it really doesn't matter but anything longer than that might start to affect your chances.

3) They'll look on consistent upward trends fairly favorably: this really depends on who's on the admissions committee but if you consistently get As in your last two years I think your first few years GPA is almost entirely irrelevant.

4) You can always try and do a combination of the two although I wouldn't know how you would achieve this in the two fields you are interested in. I will say you should just take the courses (i.e. 184 and 106) and then pick.

As for a few additional points: if you are interested in applying to research based masters programs there isn't much to worry about and you'll probably get into somewhere. If you are applying to PhDs usually getting into top programs is very difficult unless you already are working in a lab and on track to publish a paper (or multiple) especially for robotics.

history.content:
Hello! I am going to be graduating this coming spring with a Data Science degree, with the robotics emphasis. I had a pretty rough start to school, so my GPA tanked below 3.0, but I've had a recent resurgence and have been getting A's in my EECS courses, and hopefully intend to keep that track record for my remaining time here at Berkeley. The main questions I have are:

       

- How and when should I get involved in research at the EECS department? 

- I love learning, but I am feeling burned out from school and feel that I only have enough gas in the tank to last me through this final year. I would like to enter industry first so I can have a job before even considering some sort of grad school, but how will that affect my ability to enter grad school?

- How would grad admissions officers treat someone like me? Meaning someone who did poorly their first couple years, but heavily improved toward the tail end of UG in upper division courses? Is there anything else I can do at this point? 

- I have not taken 184, but plan to in the spring. It is the class I have anticipated most, and I really, really enjoy looking at the material in that course. I am also very fond of robotics courses, and I plan on taking 106a and 106b in my final year, and one of my favorite courses was EE192. How do people who have multiple interests settle on something they want to dedicate themselves to?

Of course a lot could change in my final year, but I've taken many courses at this point, and feel like my interests now are the strongest I've ever had. At this point I am just looking for more direction so I can commit myself to something. If you have any advice to offer for any of these questions, I would greatly appreciate it. Thank you.
history.subject: Advice for robotics/graphics research + grad school.
